messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Tanslation help on a page please
messages.msgSnippet: Richard- In the book Suishinshi Masahide to sono ichimon, there is an oshigata of a similar tsuba and a few lines, explaining that he indeed did make more but
messages.messageBody:
Richard-
In the book Suishinshi Masahide to sono ichimon, there is an
oshigata of a similar tsuba and a few lines, explaining that he
indeed did make more but not many. If I understood correctly all iron
tosho style tsuba appropriately enough. I would love to see one in
person myself.
Your page says; This is a Tosho tsuba with kokuin impressed in a
tsuchime-ji by Suishinshi Masahide. Masahides' great contribution to
the world of the Japanese sword is evidenced by one well known fact,
and that is that the Shinshinto era begins with the emergence of this
very artist. His strength, his energy are evidenced by his having
answered the demands of the times all the while fostering over 100
students. He was an extraordinary educator.
In Token Benkyo Kai first place is Ten (Heaven), second place is Chi
(Earth) and third place is "Jin" (Man). With this work Masahide makes
reference to that as well as Buddhistic themes. It is thought with
this tsuba Masahide is showing us a miniature universe, his kokuin
reading "Niten" is an abbreviation of Nitenji, a guardian deity who
is the same as Nichirin (the orb of heaven, the sun).
In Bunsei Gannen Masahide changed his name to Amahide, one story has
it that the "Ama" was granted to him by lord Akimoto, suggesting a
link to the first great swordsmith Amakuni and "lord of swordmakers
heaven."
The metal is a bit on the hard side but the color and texture are
excellent, this is a rare and well known piece.

At least that is what I think it says...
-t

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Sword has arrive.
messages.msgSnippet: Richard, To  and fuji are the same kanji but what you read as wara was Minamoto , they resemble each other, I am not sure of the meaning of shinto in
messages.messageBody:
Richard,
'To' and 'fuji' are the same kanji but what you read as 'wara' was
'Minamoto', they resemble each other, I am not sure of the meaning of
'shinto' in this context, perhaps Afu could help.
Alan

----- Original Message -----
From: "Richard Turner" <ikkanshi@...>
To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Thursday, January 12, 2006 10:08 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Sword has arrive.


Alan, Patrik et all. I thought this mei read Shin Fujiwara Yoshikuni and
was having trouble finding a listing. Is the Shin and Fuji characters
Shinto ( an alternative reading ) or is Shin just an abreviation for
Shinto.

Cheers

Richard Turner

Alan Bale wrote:

>It is signed Shinto Minamoto Yoshikuni and dated Kansei 7 (1795), probably
>the 3rd-4th generation, lived at Morioka in Mutsu.
>Alan
>
>----- Original Message -----
>From: "Patrik Danielsson" <patrik.danielsson@...>
>To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
>Sent: Thursday, January 12, 2006 8:33 PM
>Subject: [nihontostudy] Sword has arrive.
>
>
>Hello to you alla again.
>
>The sword has arrived, it was much better that i thought it would be, the
>blade has a lot of dried oil on it , need to get this off in a nice and
>smoth way, and i FINALY get the Tsuka off it, i understand why the former
>owner didnt want to take it off, the mekugi has been there for a long time.
>But anyway i did found Mei on both sides of the Nakago, i have taken 2
>pictures of it , more comming on the blade, mountings,and saya, when my
>camera are ready again.
>Can anyone translate the mei´s on it???
>
>Here is the links for the pictures.
>
>Picture one:
>
>http://i19.photobucket.com/albums/b196/swedeman/japan2/Side1.jpg
>
>Picture two
>
>http://i19.photobucket.com/albums/b196/swedeman/japan2/Side2.jpg
>
>
>Best Regards
>
>Patrik
>

messages.subject: Tanslation help on a page please
messages.msgSnippet: All, in my slow and never ending study on the Suishinshi Masahide mon, I came across ( whilst searching for Nobuiye documents ) a tsuba made by Suishinshi
messages.messageBody:
All, in my slow and never ending study on the Suishinshi Masahide mon, I
came across ( whilst searching for Nobuiye documents ) a tsuba made by
Suishinshi Masahide. This is like a double whammy for me LOL.

This is the first time I have seen documentation of Masahide making
tsuba and it is very interesting for me. I am now on a search for more
info to see if he made more than this one.

I have this page supplied below and would really appreciate an accurate
( or as accurate as possible ) translation if someone has the time. I
can get all the standard Tsuba/Nihotno related Kanji but it is stringing
it all together that stumps me.

And if anyone ever sees anything like this for sale, please please let
me know.

Thanks for any assistance.

Rich

http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/rt/Masahide-tsuba.jpg

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Sword has arrive.
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Patrik, thanks for he photo, this mei is a very gimei Inoue Shinkai. There are a lot of terms for swords and fittings, a huge amount to learn. Aside form
messages.messageBody:
Hi Patrik, thanks for he photo, this mei is a very gimei Inoue Shinkai.
There are a lot of terms for swords and fittings, a huge amount to
learn. Aside form all the usual books, there are two websites I can
recommend for swords.

Dr Rich Steins THE JAPANESE SWORD INDEX -
http://www.geocities.com/alchemyst/nihonto.htm

and Osaru san's JAPANESE SWORD SCHOOL-
http://www.hi-net.zaq.ne.jp/osaru/e_index.htm

Spend a bit ( = lots ) of time at these two sites, they both have a lot
of information.

Cheers

Richard

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Sword has arrive.
messages.msgSnippet: Hello Richard. Thanks for that addvices, the Kozuka is not signed, its just the Kogatana that is signed,(trying to learn all the right names of the swordparts)
messages.messageBody:
Hello Richard.

Thanks for that addvices, the Kozuka is not signed, its just the Kogatana that is signed,(trying to learn all the right names of the swordparts) :-).
i add a picture at:

http://i19.photobucket.com/albums/b196/swedeman/JapaneseSword/Mei.jpg





Best Regards

Patrik



----- Original Message -----
From: Richard Turner
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Saturday, January 14, 2006 12:21 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Sword has arrive.


Hi Patrik, if by Kazuka, then it is a Kozuka, it is actually the handle
of the utility knife. Is this section signed ?, the blade ( called dos
Kogatana ) is signed, but is too small and obscured to read. You should
find that, after wrapping the blade in some cloth like cotton or
something ( in case the kogatana is sharp ) you can pull the blade
straight out of the handle. Once out, you can photograph the whole blade
cleanly and see all the mei. Also, usually these mei can e very worn and
hard to read.

Cheers

Richard

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Sword has arrive.
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Patrik, if by Kazuka, then it is a Kozuka, it is actually the handle of the utility knife. Is this section signed ?, the blade ( called dos Kogatana ) is
messages.messageBody:
Hi Patrik, if by Kazuka, then it is a Kozuka, it is actually the handle
of the utility knife. Is this section signed ?, the blade ( called dos
Kogatana ) is signed, but is too small and obscured to read. You should
find that, after wrapping the blade in some cloth like cotton or
something ( in case the kogatana is sharp ) you can pull the blade
straight out of the handle. Once out, you can photograph the whole blade
cleanly and see all the mei. Also, usually these mei can e very worn and
hard to read.

Cheers

Richard

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Sword has arrive.
messages.msgSnippet: Hello again. Now i have cleaned the blade from that old grease (almost all of it), in my opinon i thinks its look ok, some small rust spots on the kissaki, not
messages.messageBody:
Hello again.

Now i have cleaned the blade from that old grease (almost all of it), in my opinon i thinks its look ok, some small rust spots on the kissaki, not any big damages on the blade it so i think its ok, in the higher part of it someone have tuched it in a bad way i think, im pretty sure that the guy that put the fingers there dont tuch a Japanese sword again whitout thinking twice before he does it..... he leaved spots on it from when he tuch it on both sides of the edge of the blade, and im pretty sure that he cut the fingers on it, kind of bad...it was and it is really sharp.

Also have some pictures of the Saya here, what about the iron work on tip of the Saya?? was that normal?

And now the final question, can anyone tell me about the Mei´s on the "Kazuka"??

Here is the final photos of it, its hard to take good picture of a blade that the flash just fight back from.

http://photobucket.com/albums/b196/swedeman/JapaneseSword/


Thanks again to you all for all the help.

Best Regards

Patrik


----- Original Message -----
From: Richard Turner
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, January 12, 2006 11:08 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Sword has arrive.


Alan, Patrik et all. I thought this mei read Shin Fujiwara Yoshikuni and
was having trouble finding a listing. Is the Shin and Fuji characters
Shinto ( an alternative reading ) or is Shin just an abreviation for
Shinto.


Cheers

Richard Turner

messages.msgSnippet: Hi Patrik,                         from one amateur to another,  congradulations on your purchase!  I hope the excitement of those
messages.messageBody:
Hi Patrik,
                        from one amateur to another,  congradulations on
your purchase!  I hope the excitement of those first few purchases never
wears thin.
 
Mark

-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com]On
Behalf Of Patrik Danielsson
Sent: Thursday, January 12, 2006 4:34 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [nihontostudy] Sword has arrive.


Hello to you alla again.

The sword has arrived, it was much better that i thought it would be, the
blade has a lot of dried oil on it , need to get this off in a nice and
smoth way, and i FINALY get the Tsuka off it, i understand why the former
owner didnt want to take it off, the mekugi has been there for a long time.
But anyway i did found Mei on both sides of the Nakago, i have taken 2
pictures of it , more comming on the blade, mountings,and saya, when my
camera are ready again.
Can anyone translate the mei´s on it???

Here is the links for the pictures.

Picture one:

HYPERLINK
"http://i19.photobucket.com/albums/b196/swedeman/japan2/Side1.jpg"http://i19
.photobucket.com/albums/b196/swedeman/japan2/Side1.jpg

Picture two

HYPERLINK
"http://i19.photobucket.com/albums/b196/swedeman/japan2/Side2.jpg"http://i19
.photobucket.com/albums/b196/swedeman/japan2/Side2.jpg


Best Regards

Patrik

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Sword has arrive.
messages.msgSnippet: It is signed Shinto Minamoto Yoshikuni and dated Kansei 7 (1795), probably the 3rd-4th generation, lived at Morioka in Mutsu. Alan ... From: Patrik
messages.messageBody:
It is signed Shinto Minamoto Yoshikuni and dated Kansei 7 (1795), probably
the 3rd-4th generation, lived at Morioka in Mutsu.
Alan

----- Original Message -----
From: "Patrik Danielsson" <patrik.danielsson@...>
To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Thursday, January 12, 2006 8:33 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Sword has arrive.


Hello to you alla again.

The sword has arrived, it was much better that i thought it would be, the
blade has a lot of dried oil on it , need to get this off in a nice and
smoth way, and i FINALY get the Tsuka off it, i understand why the former
owner didnt want to take it off, the mekugi has been there for a long time.
But anyway i did found Mei on both sides of the Nakago, i have taken 2
pictures of it , more comming on the blade, mountings,and saya, when my
camera are ready again.
Can anyone translate the mei´s on it???

Here is the links for the pictures.

Picture one:

http://i19.photobucket.com/albums/b196/swedeman/japan2/Side1.jpg

Picture two

http://i19.photobucket.com/albums/b196/swedeman/japan2/Side2.jpg


Best Regards

Patrik

messages.subject: Sword has arrive.
messages.msgSnippet: Hello to you alla again. The sword has arrived, it was much better that i thought it would be, the blade has a lot of dried oil on it , need to get this off in
messages.messageBody:
Hello to you alla again.

The sword has arrived, it was much better that i thought it would be, the blade has a lot of dried oil on it , need to get this off in a nice and smoth way, and i FINALY get the Tsuka off it, i understand why the former owner didnt want to take it off, the mekugi has been there for a long time.
But anyway i did found Mei on both sides of the Nakago, i have taken 2 pictures of it , more comming on the blade, mountings,and saya, when my camera are ready again.
Can anyone translate the mei´s on it???

Here is the links for the pictures.

Picture one:

http://i19.photobucket.com/albums/b196/swedeman/japan2/Side1.jpg

Picture two

http://i19.photobucket.com/albums/b196/swedeman/japan2/Side2.jpg


Best Regards

Patrik
